I -- first off, I'm -- thank goodness for Cuomo. I used to send him notes as people moved to Florida. Thank you. Keep raising taxes. It's great for Florida. Keep raising that regulation. The same thing. What are these states thinking? If you keep raising taxes, what's going to happen to their citizens? They're moving. They can't pay those taxes. And it's impossible to do business up there. So they're going to just keep moving and moving and moving to Florida. So I don't -- it's a death spiral for the -- by the way, Neil, think about it. Their most productive citizens that pay the highest taxes are the ones that keep moving. And so what happens to their tax structure? They have to keep raising taxes on everybody else. Who's it hurt? The poorest. The poorest. There's less money for roads, for schools, for all the things that the poor need to get ahead.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But you know what is interesting, Senator? This wouldn't be an issue for the president, and given his wealth, that he would really care that there's a limit on how much taxes you can write off in a state to $10,000. But for people far less wealthy who are facing this conundrum, that's a big reason to leave these high-tax states. Do you think that Republicans, Democrats ought to work together to address that, that limitation that was really -- they came up with that to make the numbers match -- I know what the drill was and all -- and to get this all done, but that that boomeranged. And while the goal was to send a message to high-tax states that maybe you have got to watch your spending, not one of them has, and yet those hurt in this process are those who are trying to stay.

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.utterance: First off, Neil, people were moving before the tax cut. On top of that, why should Florida citizens pay for the state government of New York? Think about it. We have about three million more people than New York, and their budget is almost double ours. Why would Floridians have to pay for that? Why would Texans have to pay for that? The states that focus on keeping their governments small, they're -- what's happening is, people are moving to those states. And the two beneficiaries are Texas and Florida. And it's because we don't have an income tax. We have lower overall taxes. We have less regulation. And we're nice places to live. And -- but New York, I mean, there -- and, by the way, we have pension plans that are better funded. We have better roads than they have. We have better schools. We're the -- Florida is number one in higher education in the entire country right now, second lowest tuition. There's something going on here that New York is not doing.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: No, you're right about that. You're right, that there is a draw here, because it's been proven in not only states like Florida, but in Texas, in Nevada, where a lot of Californians are moving. I'm just wondering how this is sorted out. This is the same day we have learned, Senator, as you know, that your colleague Elizabeth Warren has come up with a plan, Medicare for all, that calls for a lot more taxes, about $35 trillion over the next 10 years. And, as you know, as a former businessman, that that is not a static number. The wealthy and corporations, they can find ways to avoid that or get out of Dodge to not have to deal with that. What do you think of it?

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.utterance: Well, there's -- there ultimately will be a process where states will go bankrupt. They can't pay their pensions. They can't pay off their debt. There's going to have to be a process eventually like what's happening with Puerto Rico right now. Number two, think about Elizabeth Warren's plan. Whether it's $20 trillion, $30 trillion, $52 trillion, whoever -- whatever the number is, it's basically a double. So whatever you're paying in taxes now, because it's going to be a double. The federal government only collects $3 trillion a year now. And so, if it's $30 trillion, that's a double. That's -- that's $3 trillion a year. That's a double in your taxes. So it doesn't matter at what income bracket you are. You should assume your taxes are going to have to double.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, it wouldn't double for everybody.

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.utterance: And you're going to lose your health care.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Well, it wouldn't double for everybody, right? The numbers are staggering, but we would be taking in double the total revenue that we're taking now, if she gets -- if she gets in and if she gets her way. We will see. Senator, thank you very much. Feel better. You sound like you got a cold or something. All right?

utterances.speaker: SCOTT
utterances.utterance: I'm good. The allergies in D.C.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I hear you. All right, thank you very much. In the meantime, to Tupelo, Mississippi, where crowds are already building up inside the arena before the president has even left Washington.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, the president is set to take off for Mississippi. He plans to talk up political achievements tonight. Kaylee McGhee joins us right now, The Washington Examiner. Kaylee, he has certainly the wind at his back with this better-than- expected jobs report today, the records in the markets. He's very fond of talking about the markets, S&P and Nasdaq at records, the Dow within about 12 points of one. I imagine that will be a big focus.

utterances.speaker: KAYLEE MCGHEE, THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER
utterances.utterance: Yes, absolutely. I mean, if Trump continues to focus on the tasks of governance and its economic improvements, it's going to -- it's going to go well for him tonight. And that's exactly what his base needs to hear right now, rather than focusing on the impeachment drama.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You know, a lot of Republicans have told him, don't get immersed in this, don't do Ukraine-like fireside chat, explaining what you did. Instead, focus on this kind of stuff. Do you think he will?

utterances.speaker: MCGHEE
utterances.utterance: I think that it's going to be hard for Trump to step away from the partisan back and forth, because he does seem pretty obsessed with the impeachment saga right now. But if he was smart, he would take a page out of former President Bill Clinton's book and focus less on the impeachment drama, and more on the other things that his administration is accomplishing, because the last thing that we need right now is what happened with Mick Mulvaney a couple of weeks ago during that press conference, when there was essentially an inadvertent implication, when he admitted that there was a kind of quid pro quo, and then he walked it back. So we don't need that right now. Trump needs to focus not on impeachment.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: So, Kaylee, when -- you're well wired into these folks. When the vote came down, as it did, on this process, and it was only Democrats voting for it, and only Republicans voting against it, and two Democrats in vulnerable districts voting against it, that's as partisan as you can get. So were Democrats surprised, the leadership surprised that, wow, this does look like a cabal?

utterances.speaker: MCGHEE
utterances.utterance: Yes, and it's interesting. It'll be interesting to see moving forward what the rest of the Democratic Party does, especially in the Senate, and as well as some Republicans that have voiced concerns about the impeachment saga as well. We have heard from Mitt Romney and a few other moderates that they could perhaps join the Democrats on the impeachment side. So focusing on that during tonight's rally for Trump would probably energize his base quite a bit. But it's important to keep in mind that his base is not representative of the general electorate. And if you look at recent polls, it does show that support for impeachment is gradually increasing.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But in the battleground states, it's still more than half who don't want to see it, right?

utterances.speaker: MCGHEE
utterances.utterance: Right. And I think that that's because the general electorate is just pretty fed up with the drama at this point. They don't really want to be dragged into the back and forth. They do want to focus on the economic approval and all of those other things that actually make a difference back at home.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Kaylee, thank you very, very much. We will watch it closely. Still keeping an eye out in the president the South Lawn there, when he hops on Marine One to leave. All right, in the meantime, Martin Scorsese's got a new gangster flick out. Now, I don't know what's more shocking here, the new de-aging technology -- it's wild -- or Robert De Niro playing an Irishman.

utterances.speaker: ROBERT DE NIRO, ACTOR
utterances.utterance: Back then, there was nobody in this country who didn't know who Jimmy Hoffa was.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED ACTOR
utterances.utterance: Get that gun out of his hand!

utterances.speaker: DE NIRO
utterances.utterance: You always charge a guy with a gun. With a knife, you run away. So, you charge with a gun. With a knife, you run.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, now, the question is, will people be running to theaters, the few of them that are showing "The Irishman," or just wait a few weeks, when Netflix will stream it for any one of them who wants to do it? Let's ask our very august panel here as we get going, "Your World" audio technician and author Dion Baia. We got Rebelle Communications founder Laura Fink back with us, Spectator USA's Melissa Chen. Melissa, it's a big movie. It's a big event. I had a devil of a time finding where it would play by me. So when they say a select few theaters, it's a select few theaters.

utterances.speaker: MELISSA CHEN, SPECTATOR USA
utterances.utterance: Right. Right.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What do you think?

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: Well, firstly, I'm a millennial. And I can tell you for a fact that we just -- we just don't go out. And the value proposition of Netflix, I mean, the chill part notwithstanding, it's just too high. You can just watch the same movie. And it's a 3.5-hour epic?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Don't go in with a large drink.

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: It just seems like a long time.

utterances.speaker: DION BAIA, AUDIO TECHNICIAN
utterances.utterance: Yes, and I feel like a lot of younger people may not even care that it's a Martin Scorsese-Robert De Niro-Joe Pesci film.

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: They don't. They don't.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Not like older generations, who will go flock to the theater.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I think she's just cheap.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Right?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: No, but, I mean, also, nowadays, people don't want to go spend 20 bucks for a ticket, another 20 bucks for a popcorn and soda, when you can just sit at home in your underwear and have a beer and just watch it and pause it whenever you want.

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Just seeing you doing that, it's just unsettling.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: The lure of the theater, I think, is going away, sadly.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What do you think, Laura?

utterances.speaker: LAURA FINK, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST
utterances.utterance: But let's think about this. This is truly middle-aged man candy. So you're going to see middle-aged men flocking to the arty-farty theaters, grabbing a bag of real popcorn and sitting down and watching it. I really think the big...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Someone has a bit of an attitude.

utterances.speaker: FINK
utterances.utterance: Well, I like -- who doesn't like middle-aged man candy? I will be there watching it.

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: There is a sweet spot.

utterances.speaker: FINK
utterances.utterance: There is.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But it's long. And I guess the idea, it's for Oscar qualification.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think you have to -- for them to qualify for the Oscar, it has to show in select cities for a certain limited amount of time.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But only three weeks later, to her point, you can watch it at home.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Well, that's the problem, is that theaters initially balked because they didn't want to put it against and take up screening houses because -- instead of having a Marvel movie or something big that's a guaranteed shoo- in to take up the theater space.

utterances.speaker: FINK
utterances.utterance: Yes. But the thing is, the theaters will make their money in the first four weeks. That's been proven time and time again. And so I would say, just to quote "The Godfather" or one of "The Godfather"s, leave the gun, take the cannoli. Make your money.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: But they were worried about that. They thought that people would stay at home and not just -- wait a month and they won't come into the theaters. And they would lose that space.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: It's a different world.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Speaking of Netflix, they're doing -- they're testing this playback speeds so that you can -- when you the stream something, you stream a little faster. You get a little bit more. Is that a problem?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: I think it's a big problem. And I think it's the future, like we used to see when we used to get mad about having commercials in the theater. And now, all of a sudden, that's commonplace. Where what they're doing is, they're speeding it up just enough, but they're keeping the audio level the same. And it's for people, say, on Netflix, if you want to binge six hours, you can maybe do it in five-and-a- half. We're seeing that already on TV, like networks do that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: And you don't notice it?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: I think once you call attention to it, you can notice it. And networks do it now to get extra commercials in. But for the filmmakers' point of view, it ruins the experience of you wanting to get those emotional moments or the beats of the movie, because it's suddenly very -- faster.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Would it make a big difference to you?

utterances.speaker: FINK
utterances.utterance: I like to see movies in the theaters. I like to go and I like the experience. And I think this is going to be really fun, because if you go to those art house shops, which usually have BBC watchers, now you're going to have UFC watchers in the same theater. I will grab a bag of popcorn for that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, but at first blush, when I heard about this, I thought, all right, you are speeding up a little bit. Where is the problem with this?

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: I personally don't -- I don't care, because I do that to my podcasts.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: You do?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: Right. Like, I listen to my podcasts at like 2X speed.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Does your voice sound like...

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Well, they're doing it on years too. They do that.

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: It's just faster, so you can just consume more.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: If you listen to commercials on radio, they're like -- and that's how it sounds nowadays. And people get used to that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Really? I understood every word you just said.

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: Like the medication ads, like when they're like the side effects.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: He's on medication right now.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: How did you know?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Popeyes chicken is back with a sandwich. And I think all is right with the world. This chicken is all the rage. You guys enraged?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Not at all.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: No?

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What do you think of this?

utterances.speaker: FINK
utterances.utterance: Well, I love that this is like a chicken war between Chick-fil-A and Popeyes, with Chick-fil-A accidentally rolling out their chicken sandwich on Sunday, when they're closed, and Popeyes...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Did they not know that? What happened to -- marketing chief, one problem here?

utterances.speaker: FINK
utterances.utterance: Fumbled the football, fumbled the football. But I love the way that the Popeyes marketing team threw some shade and was able to capitalize on that. We will see who's picking up the chicken.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: But that's the draw. And McDonald's is odd man out.

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: Or KFC. I mean, they have the market on chicken.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: Do you think it's really such a big deal, in the sense of...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Bigger than the speeding up playback.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: But he's doing so good after getting out of the Navy, Popeye.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, let me switch gears a little bit. There are -- scientists are actually working on a pill to erase, just eradicate any bad memories. What do you think of that?

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: That's an interesting development. I mean, I could see it being good for PTSD, certain people that have really traumatic...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What about you, if have you very unpleasant memories, like this experience here with Dion?

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Would you welcome a pill to just eradicate?

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: Yes, there's probably one memory I would. I definitely remember wetting my bed as a child. And ever since that one experience, every time I need to go to the restroom, like, in bed, it's just -- I'm just taking off. It's just like that one thing. And it's just -- at this age, it's just embarrassing. I would like to get rid of that memory.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: What do you think?

utterances.speaker: CHEN
utterances.utterance: I really would.

utterances.speaker: FINK
utterances.utterance: Well, two things. One, I don't know if you know this, but the precursor to this, the science was done by a couple of Ph.D.s that made a bet about four rats and a bottle of tequila. And that was the path.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Sounds like a bad joke. Two rats walk into a bar. Yes.

utterances.speaker: FINK
utterances.utterance: And so that was the origin of this. But I think it's great for PTSD survivors, potentially. I think the ethics are -- can be questionable. If you want to forget a bad boyfriend, or maybe 60 percent of Americans may want to forget the last four years, I...

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Oh, listen to you.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Always a little Trump zinger.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: I mean, to make a joke out of it, I thought that's what booze was for, to forget this. How can you take a pill and have it selective remember just that memory? We're getting into that "Total Recall" territory, "We Can Remember It Wholesale," that Philip K. Dick story.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I always worry, with this kind of stuff.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: That's what lobotomies are for as well.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: Yes. But whatever your justification, be careful what memories you remove.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: How is the pill going to know what memory you wanted to erase without...

utterances.speaker: FINK
utterances.utterance: Well, the way that it works is that you have to go through the process of repeating the memory. And then it has to do with the proteins and whether or not they're assigned to it.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: And then God forbid if you get the wrong memory, and then all of a sudden, you're like, oh.

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: But certainly, what you -- Melissa said, that it is for PTSD and stuff, like very traumatic stuff.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: I understand that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: The bad memory of someone else is a good memory...

utterances.speaker: BAIA
utterances.utterance: They were doing it in the '60s with lobotomies.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: That's a great reminder. All right, guys, I want to thank you all. Sorry I had to motor through this. We're trying to stay one step ahead of the president of the United States. By the way, he will be going to this big rally in Mississippi. And you can bet, you can bet he is going to talk a lot about economic numbers out today and a big old tax hike he says Elizabeth Warren is planning for you tomorrow, or something like that.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, I always tell you, do not, not, not pay attention to the polls, but, man, have you seen this latest one that has come out that could spell some trouble for Joe Biden? Peter Doocy has much more. Hey, Peter.

utterances.speaker: PETER DOOCY, CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: Neil, even though Joe Biden got into the race later than most Democrats, he shot right to the top of the polls, but now he is falling back to earth, fourth place in The New York Times/Siena College poll of Iowa Democrats, behind Pete Buttigieg, Bernie Sanders, and Elizabeth Warren, who is in Iowa right now after a stop in New Hampshire, where she agreed two million jobs could be lost if Medicare for all becomes law of the land. And, today, she explained what would happen to people who work for private insurance companies.

utterances.speaker: WARREN
utterances.utterance: Some of the people currently working in health insurance will work in other parts of insurance, in life insurance, in auto insurance, in car insurance. Some will work for Medicaid.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY
utterances.utterance: Kamala Harris also in Iowa. That's the state her campaign is dedicating almost all their resources to. We confirmed this afternoon she is shuttering three New Hampshire field offices, and all New Hampshire field staffers of hers have been fired -- Neil.

utterances.speaker: CAVUTO
utterances.utterance: All right, my friend, thank you very, very much, Peter Doocy, following all of that. By the way, we're going to be monitoring all this, this weekend, as we do every Saturday, live on "Cavuto Live." We will be speaking with, among others, Democratic candidate Tom Steyer, what he makes of this whole tax-the-rich-scheme on the part of Elizabeth Warren, also the House Freedom Caucus chair Andy Biggs on the Democrats' impeachment push. That, a look at markets and trade, your money, your life, your everything. Here comes "The Five." Content and Programming Copyright 2019 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
